subject: Re: new mapping proposal
msgSnippet: ... Coincidently ... was ... it ... maps ... I think I should have also pointed out that it is quite easy to remember where most keys are using these guides:
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "peter_r_guinness"
<malt99@...> wrote:
>
> I see key mappings are currently being discussed again.
Coincidently
> I have just created a new mapping. The design goal of my mapping
was
> for text to be readable when viewed without a quickscript font.
Eg:
> when websurfers view a page that is written with quikscript but
> don't have the appropriate QS font can still attempt to read the
> page when their browser defaults to an english font. Consequently
it
> tries to use mappings that most readers are used to eg: 'y' key
maps
> to 'ye', and 'j' maps to 'jay'.
> I welcome any feedback coments to improve my mapping.
.....
> -----------------------
>
>
> The mapping is:
>
> pea <-> p
>
> bay <-> y
>
> tea <-> t
>
> day <-> d
>
> key <-> k
>
> gay <-> g
>
> thaw <-> T
>
> they <-> D
>
> fee <-> f
>
> vie <-> v
>
> see <-> s
>
> zoo <-> z
>
> she <-> S
>
> j'ai <-> Z
>
> cheer <-> C
>
> jay <-> j
>
> ye <-> y
>
> way <-> w
>
> he <-> h
>
> why <-> W
>
> ing <-> N
>
> may <-> m
>
> no <-> n
>
> low <-> l
>
> roe <-> r
>
> it <-> i
>
> eat <-> E
>
> et <-> e
>
> eight <-> A
>
> at <-> a
>
> I <-> I
>
> ah <-> R
>
> awe <-> Q : alternative- ö
>
> ox <-> o
>
> oy <-> q
>
> utter <-> u : alternatives- à è
>
> out <-> H
>
> owe <-> O
>
> foot <-> V
>
> ooze <-> U
>
> null (ie: no character) <-> È
>
> Note 1 : I assume that it is possible to map a key to a nothing,
> specifically: 'È' maps to a null character. Is it possible to do
> this?
> Note 2 : For 'utter' there are multiple mappings. The primary one
> to use is 'u' but if you need to improve the english font
> readability you may use either 'à' or 'è' so that the word being
> typed looks similar to the TO spelling.
> Note 3 : For 'awe' there is an alternate mapping. The primary one
> to use is 'Q' but use 'ö' to when wishing to improve english font
> readability.
>


I think I should have also pointed out that it is quite easy to
remember where most keys are using these guides:

-all lower case consonants keys that are used in the mapping say the
usual sound that everyday people are familiar with already. eg: 'b'
maps to bay, 'j' to jay, 'y' to ye, etc. Except for 'q', but 'q' by
itself almost never occurs in normal written english and so doesn't
have much in the way of its own sound anyway.

- an upper case for a constant indicates that it does not say the
usual sound. The upper case constant mappings basically follows the
other key mapping proposals.

-all lower case vowel keys say the usual short vowel sounds: ie: 'a
e i o u' map to the sounds in the words 'bat', 'bet', 'bit', 'bot'
(british english accent - not merged american) and 'but'
respectively.

-all upper case vowels say their own name: ie: 'A E I O U' map to
the sounds in the words 'say', 'see', 'sigh', 'sew', 'sue' (well 'U'
sort of does)

-upper case 'R' says its own name. ie: 'R' maps to the vowel sound
in 'car'

-that just leaves the other three vowel sounds to find mappings for.
These mappings have to be learnt- 'q' maps to 'oi' (which is the
original mapping), 'H' maps to 'out' (which is the sampa mapping -
actually having reviewed this again I think it should map to
something else so that 'H' can be used as a null character) and
lastly 'V' maps to 'foot'.
